author: @ericsabbath
text: Great discussion, comrades! My organization @unidademarxista (Brazil) has a very similar critique to the CPGB-ML on most matters. We've come to know CPGB-ML from the World Anti-Imperialist Platform, which we fully subscribe to. Lot of feminists (radical, eco, materialist, gender critical, marxist and even dysphoric females who reject queer theory) are joining us due to the neoliberal queer agenda over women being hegemonic and violently imposed by almost all other left and marxist brazilian organizations and by the current bourgeois workers party government. Brazil has been taken by american and european NGOs since the 2013 psyops to oust President Dilma Rousseff, impeached in 2016 in a soft coup, steal our oil, water and lands and keep our peoples under the boot of the US.

We have nothing against what people look like, if they change their names or whatever, as long as they don't try to take over other minorities spaces,  rights and fights and then blame them for criticizing it. We do accept (and already have) L, G, B and T members, as long as they're not advocating for Butler's queer theory and trying to erase biological sex, historical feminism and social science. Trans people should be protected, but ideology is not people. Queer advocates (mostly "cis" actually) are the ones who won't take any critique and then try to ruin working peoples lives through persecution, doxxing and institutional lawfare. We are not transphobic and we are not trying to get anyone beat up, unlike you JK Rowling-obsessed guys.

author: @ai_serf
text: wow a lot to think about. first time i heard the idea that the government wants us to be on drugs, and by war of prohibition, it's the perfect mechanism to drug delivery while appearing like you don't want them, plus you get to be a fasicst. double win for liberal democracy.

replies.author: @hansfrankfurter2903
replies.text:
Not quite. The drug phenomenon is itself a byproduct of the capitlaist status quo with ppl overworking, being stressed out and looking for an out to their suffering. Remember opium addiction was a thing in China in the late 19th century before capital even developed much and before any ‚Äúwar on drugs‚Äù . Toil and misery is the demand side, the supply side is either the gov (brits in china) or the black market where secretly backed organized crime supplies it. 

The gov promoted drug culture in the 60s as a kind of dreamy escapism from any kind of genuine radical struggle . And you see this today in folks like Joe Rogan and derivatives of the psychedelic movement. They sell drugs and drug culture as a solution to social ills. As some form of gateway to freeing your mind and seeing ‚Äúthe truth‚Äù that will finally let you be truely free and happy..etc. it has almost a religious connotation to it, not too different from the way Dharmic cultures sold their own religions as ‚Äúsalvation‚Äù from suffering. TLDR its a distraction. 

Obviously it wouldnt work if drugs were just legalized and regulated. That would totally take off the edge of it being counter cultural, thus the ‚Äúwar on drugs‚Äù. 

Another reason is that , its a massive black budget to use to fund illegal or grey programs outside of public oversight. Not to mention that much of this organized crime can be used as indirect enforcers of the elite, in case doing through official channels is risky. In other words there‚Äôs a quasi ‚Äúbrown shirt‚Äù element to the whole thing. 

Anyhow cheers

author: @TabascoRain
text: People need to read Losurdo's Class Struggle and IMO steer away from obsessively attacking identity politics. While it is true that identity has been manipulated by the ruling class as an alternative to class politics, identity affirmations nonetheless have an important role to play in countering the age-old, divide-and-conquer strategy, just as reformist material palliatives have an important role in preventing class divisions within working class minority populations.

replies.author: @TabascoRain
replies.text: The material basis of the family has yielded a near-complete evisceration of social reproduction, even as late capitalism has yielded the partly emancipatory participation of women in the workforce. Nancy Fraser ("Cannibal Capitalism") covers this subject capably, and suggests post-capitalist cultural horizon to accompany the pro-social economic outcome of accelerating collapse of imperial capitalism.

replies.author: @hansfrankfurter2903
replies.text: Ive never seen anyone properly define what is this ‚Äúidentity politics‚Äù they keep whining about. I agree alot of co opting and redirection and midirection has occurred but this framing of everything i dont like is ‚Äúidentity politics ‚Äú just seems lazy and spineless tbh,

author: @reel9877
text: Some good, some bad. Perhaps we can become fit, sober, intellectually rigorous and optimistic revolutionaries without becoming fanatically anti-academic, transphobic types. Approach transgender people with empathy. Speak to them, befriend them, and hear what they have to say about their experience. I agree that IDPOL has taken too much preference over class struggle among the western left and that the ruling class embraces identity-related struggles as "acceptable and approved" struggles, but I feel that the more we focus our attention on "combating IDPOL" and delving into outright transphobia that we run the risk of becoming the other side of that coin; we will make the culture war the focus of our attention and let cultural differences divide us. Would it not be more productive to ignore and denounce the culture war altogether, to unite the blue haired baristas with the MAGA truckers under the banner of class struggle? Further, just because the ruling class puts identity politics on a pedestal to be a red herring for would-be revolutionaries, it does not necessarily mean that identity related struggles are "bad" and not worth engaging in, they should not take priority over class struggle. Thoughts on this take?

replies.author: @MariusTrotter-sw1ml
replies.text:
Gender nonconforming individuals have the right to live their own lives without being bothered or discriminated against, sure. They have the right to respect, yes. They do not have the right, however, to redefine reality for the rest of us. When anyone, of any identity, makes the absurd claim that men ovulate, or men can get pregnant, or describe women as 'womb carriers', I have the right to treat such nonsense with the derision, mockery and contempt it deserves. That's not hatred, that's respect for intelligence and common sense. 

Gender nonconforming men who live 'as women' exist in numerous cultures all over the world, yet they do not try to coerce people into accepting them literally AS women, nor do they launch political campaigns demanding access to regular women's spaces. That is a peculiar aspect of the toxic, narcissistic, corporate backed LGBTQ culture that exists in the West. 'Transphobic' is a term weaponized a lot like 'anti Semitism' is by Zionists- its a 'power word' used to shut down discussion by intolerant ideologues, because they know their claims cannot withstand scrutiny in open debate.

Ask they why they think blue hair and pronouns in the US is the direct cause of US intervention in Taiwan and Ukraine and they have no answer. Why? Because US imperialism utilizes any and all identity to attack its enemies: the uyghur muslims in china are weaponized, the women in iran are weaponized, the poor in cuba are weaponized. There is nothing intrinsic to gayness that makes it any better as a cudgel to attack US enemies, and this is modern history 101 level shit. Its not that they arent aware of it, its that they dont care at all because it gives them the excuse to do the transphobia and homophobia they already want to do and appeal to global conspiracy about queer people.

author: @MK-jc6us
text:
Sorry comrades but this video describe a phenomenon, it does not explain it. This video is way too long for the content it (does not) bring. To claim that the left went soft is a description that anyone sympathetic with Leninism will agree with. To have ML as a "worldview" implies going into the detail of all topics, it requires specialisation and of course professionalisation. For example,  "sexual revolution" didn't start with French guys in the 60s, Kollontai is a famous figure of this movement, this was the mood of many in Europe and Russia alike (Kollontai said a lot of crap, including her framing of raising kids like some kind of burden, her idea to "collectivise" kids is plain stupid, good it was refused by the majority). To say that the root is "over 50 years ago" (min 30), only shows that the speaker himself didn't do his homework.
Apologies in advance, I don't want to be too negative, but if the video is precisely about the decline of the left, it means that each one of us has to work to raise the bar, first in theory, then in practice. The whole issue of "patriarchy" gave much room for confusion, partially because of Engels himself and the flawed (but very bold) claims that Engels built based on Morgan very basic works about matriarchy. We know today that this interpretation is flawed, matriarchy was the rare exception even in very primitive societies. We don't need to advocate for patriarchy, but we have to correct wrong theories from the past that still influence this liberal-left worldview. The speaker mentioned Engels and his work on the subject, but only en passant, without any real critical view.
Of course, this is just an example among many, "sexual revolution" as any broad tendency, does not have only one origin. But to claim that this is from the 50s/60s is to miss the history of Leninism itself (see Zetkin's short memoir of her visit to Lenin - they discussed the topic of feminism and modernism in general).

replies.text: Marxism indeed was socially conservative, very socially conservative indeed, I grew up in a moderate socially conservative socialist country of Yugoslavia and it was even in compering with the western countries at time,pretty much socially conservative.The liberalism was considered and It is,as a product of capitalism, along with Burgoues conservatism, such as racism,sexism and stuff..Those are the opposite sides of the same coin. MARXISM aims for the emancipated,cultured,decent working class citizens.Not lumpen proleteriat self destructive values , which are humiliating human dignity and self conscious as homosappiens ,rational human beings..

replies.author: @RamenTraveler-r1y
replies.text: The idea that Marxism has to be socially conservative is nonsense. You're just going to drive away the more socially liberal members of the working class from your party for no reason.

replies.author: @feelingveryattackedrn5750
replies.text: @vannajs5024 This is just false, the USSR was in many ways socially progressive to the West, at least at its outset. Conservative is a *relative* word, Marxism wasnt a conservative philosophy at the time by any means. Conservatism as youve defined it (various forms of bigotry) was both the norm and not "product" of capitalism. Social bigotries can exist regardless of capitalism/communism, which is why Lenin takes the time to write by anti semitism and why the CCP dedicates a proportionately large part of its national peoples congress to minority representatives (even though its a dictatorship of the proletariat). You right wing morons would call this "Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion" I believe. Regardless the point remains, social understandings have advanced a lot in the last century as the world has become more globalized: just because Marx didnt himself say trans rights doesnt mean that we shouldnt let trans people have rights, unless youre suggesting that we borrow social attitudes and things like cosmography from the ancient greeks simply because their other ideas were worth internalizing.
